# CODE 3.1.1
```{r}
m0 <- rnorm(1000,0,1)
m10 <- numeric()
m100 <- numeric()
m1000 <- numeric()
for (i in 1:1000){
  m10[i] <- mean(rnorm(10,0,1))
  m100[i] <- mean(rnorm(100,0,1))
  m1000[i] <- mean(rnorm(1000,0,1))
}
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
hist(m0)
hist(m10)
hist(m100)
hist(m1000)
```

# CODE 3.1.2
```{r}
qqnorm(m0)
```

# ANSWER 3.1.2
The distribution looks normal.

# CODE 3.1.3
```{r}
m <- data.frame(m0,m10,m100,m1000)
# mean
mmean <- apply(m, 2, mean)
mmean
# var
mvar <- apply(m, 2, var)
mvar
# var ratio
mvar[1]/mvar[2:4]
```
# ANSWER 3.1.3
The means are not substantially different from each other.
The variances are different from each other. 
The ratio between Var(m0) and Var(m10),Var(m100),Var(m1000) are about 10,100,1000.
A general formula to derive the Variance of any distribution of the means XÂ¯n for any given n would be $\frac{\sigma}{n}$

# CODE 3.2.1
```{r}
r0 <- rexp(1000,1)
r10 <- numeric()
r100 <- numeric()
r1000 <- numeric()
for (i in 1:1000){
  r10[i] <- mean(rexp(10,1))
  r100[i] <- mean(rexp(100,1))
  r1000[i] <- mean(rexp(1000,1))
}
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
hist(r0)
hist(r10)
hist(r100)
hist(r1000)
```

# CODE 3.2.2
```{r}
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
qqnorm(r0)
qqnorm(r10)
qqnorm(r100)
qqnorm(r1000)
```

# ANSWER 3.2.2
The exponential values are not normally distributed. The means are normally distributed.
